description.narrative: The overall objective of the SRHR, HIV AND AIDS Governance Project (2014-2019) is to build the capacity of parliamentarians (MPs), especially women MPs, to promote, intervene and advocate for comprehensive and essential sexual reproductive health (SRH) and HIV/AIDS services and impact on relevant current policy environment in their countries in order to ensure that it is supportive of human rights and sexual and reproductive health and rights (SRHR).

Den 10 april 2014 granskade ambassadens bedömningskommitté SADC PF:s projektförslag ’SRHR & HIV/AIDS & governance, 2014-2017’. Man konstaterade då att en revidering krävdes. Mål och resultat behövde stärkas, förändringsteorin samt de logiska ramverken behövde göras mer realistiska och praktiskt genomförbara. Ambassaden gick därför in med ett förberedande stöd på 2 320 000 SEK under 6 månaders tid. Syftet med stödet var att stötta SADC PF i genomförandet av vissa aktiviteter; sätta upp baselinje data i fem av de sju utvalda länderna för genomförande (Tanzania, Zimbabwe, Angola, Mauritius och Zambia); stärka den tekniska resurserna bland medarbetare; genomföra en workshop för kapacitetsuppbyggnad och utvecklandet av resultatramverket.
SADC PF har ansökt om 29 575 000 SEK i stöd för sin insats "SRHR & HIV/AIDS & Governance” i SADC regionen (Zambia, Seychellerna, Sydafrika, Tanzania, Angola, Mauritius och Zimbabwe) under genomförandeperioden 2014-2017. Genom att fokusera på SADCs kvinnliga parlamentariker och förbättra deras kunskaper kring SRHR och hiv, så syftar insatsen till att öka det politiska stödet för förbättrat tillhandahållande av SRHR-service och programintegrering av hiv i sju länder. Dessa resultat nås genom:
1. Parlamentsledamöterna i Regional Women’s Parliamentary Caucasus (RWPC) företräder och arbetar för en integrering av srhr, hiv och aidsoch förvaltningsfrågor i sina respektive ständiga utskott och politiska organ inom SADC PF. 2. Utskotten i parlamentet införlivar srhr i sina arbetsprogram beträffande tillsyn, lagstiftning och budgetmandat, i linje med nationella prioriteringar. 3. Parlamentsledamöterna i Regional Women’s Parliamentary Caucasus (RWPC) visar på ledarskap och engagemang i parlamentet för att främja specifika srhr insatser.
Den totala budgeten för insatsen är SEK 29 575 000.

To begin with, on April 10, 2014 the Embassy Appraisal Committee reviewed SADC PF's SRHR & HIV & governance 2014 - 2017 project proposal and concluded that it required content revision to strengthen the purpose, soundness and realism in the proposed objectives, the theory of change and the logical frame work. Thus, the Embassy supported SADC PF with a 6 months Preparatory Nature Agreement at 2 320 000 SEK, to achieve various activities that include; conducting a baseline survey in five of the seven implementation selected countries (Tanzania, Zimbabwe, Angola, Mauritius and Zambia), strengthen its human technical resource and manage a capacity building for results framework revision process.
As a result, a revised proposal has been submitted to the Embassy for reconsideration. The proposed intervention places importance to enhance efforts on bridging the gap between political decision-making leaders and public health evidence to inform calls for an integrated approach to SRHR and HIV. SADC PF has now applied for funding of 29 575 000 SEK to carry out the “SRHR & HIV/AIDS & Governance" in SADC region (Zambia, Seychelles, South Africa, Tanzania, Angola, Mauritius and Zimbabwe) during the period 2014-2017. The intervention aims to improve SADC women Parliamentarians skills and knowledge on SRHR and HIV in order to canvass enough political support to effectively influence service delivery on SRHR and HIV integration in seven countries, by:
1. Regional Women’s Parliamentary Caucasus (RWPC) MPs are lobbying and advocating for integrated SRHR, HIV and AIDS, and governance issues in their respective standing committees and policy organs within SADC PF. 2. Parliamentary Committees incorporate SRHR issues in their work programmes in relation to oversight, legislation and budgetary mandates in line with national priorities. 3. National Women’s Parliamentary Caucasus (NWPC) MPs demonstrate leadership and advocate for commitment of parliament to facilitate specific SRHR actions.
The intervention’s total budget is 29 575 000 million SEK.

participating-org.narrative: SADC Parliamentary Forum Programme/SADC PF–SRHR Programme
SADC Parliamentary Forum Programme/SADC PF–SRHR Programme

tag.narrative: 3.7 - By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.

3.7 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla har tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsovård, inklusive familjeplanering, information och utbildning, och att reproduktiv hälsa integreras i nationella strategier och program.

5.6 - Ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health and reproductive rights as agreed in accordance with the Programme of Action of the International Conference on Population and Development and the Beijing Platform for Action and the outcome documents of their review conferences.

5.6 - Säkerställa allmän tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och reproduktiva rättigheter i enlighet med överenskommelserna i handlingsprogrammet från den internationella konferensen om befolkning och utveckling, Pekingplattformen samt slutdokumenten från respektive översynskonferenser.

Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: The SRHR, HIV and AIDS Governance Project has been successfully implemented over the 4-year period from 1st December 2014 to 31st May 2019 in 7 participating national Parliaments. These are the national Parliaments of Lesotho, Mauritius, Namibia, Seychelles, Tanzania, Zambia and Zimbabwe. The national Parliament of Angola originally participated under the Project but was replaced by the Parliament of Namibia in 2017 due to operational reasons and the approaching general elections. Under the completed project, the Forum’s has achieved several successes that have enhanced the legal and policy framework relating to SRHR and HIV/AIDS in implementing countries, through targeted parliamentary initiatives at the legislative, budgetary, oversight and representative levels. This includes: -mainstreaming of SRHR into the parliamentary agenda of implementing countries, and the increase in SRHR oversight, legislative and representative interventions within Parliament, -institutionalization of a Monitoring and Evaluation framework within Parliaments for SRHR through the capacitation of Researchers, SADC-PF desk officers and parliaimentary staff in the Office of the Clerk in capturing data from SRHR parliamentary interventions of MPs -setting up of the Regional Parliamentary Model Laws Oversight Committee (RPMLOC) through amendments brought to the Constitution and the Rules of Procedure of the Forum, in view of having a dedicated organ to monitor the domestication of Model Laws relating to SRHR such as the SADC Model Law on Child Marriage, in collaboration with national Parliaments -mainstreaming of SRHR issues across all Standing Committees of the Forum, through individual meetings, and joint sessions which assisted in heightening awareness on key topics such as Eliminating Unwanted Pregnancy and Key Populations -development of normative content on SRHR which serve as benchmarks for national Parliaments, notably the SADC Model Law on Child Marriage and the Minimum Standards for Key Populations -capacity development of women MPs on the Regional Women Parliamentary Caucus and leadership demonstrated by women MPs on SRHR on all Standing Committees of the Forum - institutionalization and scaling up of the Gender Responsive Oversight Model (GROM) which altogether facilitates the benchmarking with the Maputo Protocol (the Protocol on the Rights of Women in Africa) -cross-learning and collaborative engagements on SRHR with other inter-parliamentary bodies/entities such as the Inter-Parliamentary Union and the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association in view of improving the synergies in the continental approach to SRHR
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
